titlestmt.author: Alice L. Poffinberger

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Lucy Monroe Calhoun family photographs and papers
did.abstract: The Lucy Monroe Calhoun family photographs and papers contains loose photographs, a photograph album, Lucy Monroe Calhoun's writings and papers, along with Monroe family papers. The photographs include 740 loose black-and-white photographs, generally developing-out paper or gelatin sliver prints, as well as 7 negatives, and one slide, all featuring images of Lucy's residences, locations in a and around Peking (Beijing), and locations elsewhere in China, Cambodia, Japan, and the Philippines between 1910 and 1932. A subset of 15 photographs contains images captured during the Peking riots of 1912. The photograph album (60 pages) contains 94 albumen prints featuring images taken during the Calhoun party's travel between China and the United States in 1911, via Siberia. The Lucy Monroe Calhoun papers series features primarily Calhoun's writings, including her 276-page memoir of her life in China (1910-1936), five typescript articles on China, as well as her letters to family members, commercial postcards, and printed material. The Monroe family papers include mainly writing by family members, from letters to autobiographical and biographical pieces, along with some photographs, postcards, and a few newspaper clippings. There are also extensive letters written by Polly Root Collier and Henry Stanton Monroe, Lucy Monroe Calhoun's niece and nephew, both of whom wrote letters to family members during their stays in China. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into the following series: Photographs, Photograph album, Lucy Monroe Calhoun papers, and Monroe family papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lucy Monroe Calhoun was born in 1865 to Henry Stanton Monroe and Martha Mitchell; she was the sister of poet and editor Harriet (Stone) Monroe. She became a freelance art critic for Chicago and national newspapers, and served as an editorial reader for the Herbert S. Stone publishing company (1898-1905). In 1904, she married William James Calhoun, who was appointed U.S. minister to China by William Howard Taft, a position he held from 1909-1913. Following her husband's death in 1916, Calhoun served in with the American Red Cross in France. In the 1920s Calhoun returned to China, established her home in an ancient temple, collected art, and became the unofficial "First Lady" of the diplomatic corps in Peking. She remained there until the Japanese occupation of Peking in 1937. She returned to the United States in 1941, and died in Chicago in 1950, at age 85.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Lucy Monroe Calhoun family photographs and papers, 1886-1973 and undated, bulk 1911-1933 were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2014-2016.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Lucy Monroe Calhoun family photographs and papers, 1886-1973 and undated, bulk 1911-1933, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2014-0114, 2015-0085, 2016-0294

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Lucy Monroe Calhoun family photographs and papers contains loose photographs, a photograph album, Lucy Monroe Calhoun's writings and papers, along with Monroe family papers. The photographs include 740 loose black-and-white photographs, generally developing-out paper or gelatin sliver prints, as well as 7 negatives, and one slide, all featuring images of Lucy's residences, locations in a and around Peking (Beijing), and locations elsewhere in China, Cambodia, Japan, and the Philippines between 1910 and 1932. A subset of 15 photographs contains images captured during the Peking riots of 1912. The photograph album (60 pages) contains 94 albumen prints featuring images taken during the Calhoun party's travel between China and the United States in 1911, via Siberia. The Lucy Monroe Calhoun papers series features primarily Calhoun's writings, including her 276-page memoir of her life in China (1910-1936), five typescript articles on China, as well as her letters to family members, commercial postcards, and printed material. The Monroe family papers include mainly writing by family members, from letters to autobiographical and biographical pieces, along with some photographs, postcards, and a few newspaper clippings. There are also extensive letters written by Polly Root Collier and Henry Stanton Monroe, Lucy Monroe Calhoun's niece and nephew, both of whom wrote letters to family members during their stays in China. Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts.

did.unittitle: Developing out paper and gelatin silver photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series includes 745 black-and-white photographs, dated 1900-1941 (most dates were assigned rather than provided), and ranging in size from 2.25 x 3.25 in. to 9.75 x 7.75 in., with the majority 4.75 x 6.75 in. There are also 7 negatives and one slide present. Staff sorted the images according to location, except for the presentation photographs, where the original order of the photographs was maintained. Images feature Lucy's residences, both in the American legation quarters and her "Temple house;" locations in and around Beijing; as well as other locations in China, Japan, Cambodia, and the Philippines. A subset of 15 photographs contains images captured during the Peking riots of 1912. There is also a folder of images of the Calhoun's that were taken in the United States.

Lucy Calhoun signed the backs of many of her photographs, but not all, and she often trimmed her photographs to 6.5x 4.5 in. and added a border in black. Eighty-seven of Calhoun's photographs were placed on mounts, and were stored in two Chinese boxes for presentation. Other than by the presence of Calhoun's markings, however, identifying the photographer for an individual photograph is difficult. Some photographs have been folded in half, a few have been hand-colored, and several have letters written on the back.

scopecontent.head: Note
scopecontent.p: Copy of RL11103-P-024.1. Letter on back of photograph is p. 2 of letter begun on RL11103-P-025.2. "curfew, we went on to the hotel and danced. We saw the New Year in at the Wagons-Sits as guests of Mr. Wowark, but the crwod went to the other hotel so it was rather dull. On New Year's Day we had a lilvely tiffin in the salon. In the afternoon the Johnsons were at home, and Jane had asked me to receive with her. I was touched. All the world came of course, and with the marine band it was very gay. We are dining there tomorrow night. Nelson was glad to have seen you in Shanghai. Many thanks for your cable. I had a huge Christmas mail which arrived just in time, and another at New Year's. I wonder if you are in Arizona, With my love, Lucy"

scopecontent.head: Note
scopecontent.p: Copy of RL11103-P-025.1. "January 3, 1932. Here is the corner of your East Court, Anna darling, under another aspect. This was taken during the heavy snow of December 21st, which gave us the most beautiful white Christmas that ever you [saw.] Clear skies and brilliant moonlight on Christmas Eve, with red lanterns in the Court, made the house a Carnival. The dinner was very gay. The Johnsons came and the Newells and the Wortons, and after dinner we had blind musicians in the salon. Quite lovely this music was, and everyone liked it. Then we had a hamper of foolish gifts which took well. As there was no midnight mass at the Pietang because of the" The letter is continued on RL11103-P-024.2.

did.unittitle: The foreign troops which were hurried to Peking at the time of the riots-Feby 29th -March 2nd, 1912, paraded and marched through the streets of the city, to make a demonstration of force and thereby to over awe the rioters. A squad of American marines--mounted on Chinese ponies--headed this column. In this picture they are standing by their horses waiting for the order to mount

scopecontent.head: Title (Chinese)
scopecontent.p: 1912年3月2号各路外国军队到达北京，他们列队在街上巡逻，威吓参加兵变的军队。一队美国海军陆战队士兵站在马旁，等待命令准备上马。

scopecontent.head: Image caption
scopecontent.p: No. 9 (No Number 8) The foreign troops which were hurried to Peking at the time of the riots-Feby 29th -March 2nd, 1912, paraded and marched through the streets of the city, to make a demonstration of force and thereby to over awe the rioters. A squad of American marines--mounted on Chinese ponies--headed this column. In this picture they are standing by their horses waiting for the order to mount.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photograph album (60 pages) contains 94 albumen prints featuring images taken during the Calhoun party's travel between China and the United States in 1911, via Siberia. The back of the album contains a handwritten itinerary including identification of people in the photographs. Among the places photographed are Peiking (Beijing); Moscow; Berlin; Marken Island; Stratford-upon-Avon and Huntingdon, England; New York; Chicago; and Paris. The photographer for individual photographs is unclear. The album has suffered damage from chewing rodents and the leather cover is deteriorating. A separate list of photograph locations is included with the album.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series features primarily Lucy Monroe Calhoun's writings, including her 276-page memoir of her life in Peking from 1911-1912 and 1921-1936, as well as five typescript articles (some of which were later published) describing Peking, travel to Jehol, the Western Hills, and her house, along with a piece entitled "My Greatest Adventure was China." There are also seven letters by Calhoun to family members, with other assorted papers; postcards of 1930 Budapest; and a few pieces of printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains Lucy Monroe Calhoun's 1936 memoir (276 pages, with forward, text, plus lists of photographs) of her life in China, primarily between 1910-1912, but also 1921-1936. She describes Peiking itself, as well as life and activities related to living in the American Legation, including dinners, entertainments, and extensive travel members participated in. Politics in China is also a major topic, especially the establishment of the Republic and the resulting change in status for the Manchu class and the Emperor. Other topics include servants, merchants and shopping, weddings, funerals, Chinese New Year, worship, and the temple house where she resided after 1921.
The undated albumen photograph features Polly Root Collier, John Wellborn Root and Ellen Root, her parents, and her husband, Edward Maverick Collier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five typescript articles written by Lucy Calhoun on Chinese topics, often with lists of photographs, all undated. Includes "Jehol by Mule-litter" (28 pages), "My Chinese House" (15 pages), untitled [on Peking] (16 pages), "The Western Hills" (31 pages), and "My Greatest Adventure was China" (27 pages), which is accompanied by a 2-page letter from an editor of the piece. The articles generally feature manuscript edits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 19 items, dated 1910-1945 and undated. There are seven letters from Lucy Calhoun to family members, mostly describing trips taken Peking, work and assistants for the Minister, dinner parties and other events planned, including reading habits and items read at a meeting of the Purple Cows, and making requests, especially that her niece, Polly Root Collier, be able to remain in China. Lucy wrote one letter from Paris in 1927, discussing Charles Lindbergh's popularity and her travel plans for return to China. There are also four letters written by a New York museum curator to Lucy, dated 1943-1945 and undated. He had been a fellow resident and friend to her in China, and in the letters he discusses his exhibitions, the war, and his desire to return to China. Other items include a bakery bill for Mrs. Russell in the American Legation, 1911; two telegrams 1911-1912; two envelopes, and an undated list of wedding presents. There are also three papers featuring Chinese characters; one of the items is identified in handwritten English as a calling card for a Mongol prince.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an accordion case containing 12 commercial postcards of Budapest, dated 1930, with images of the parliament buildings, the Royal Castle, bridges, and the railway station, among others. There are also 13 undated postcards of China, including images of the Temple of Heaven and the Marco Polo bridge, with other locations unidentified. Seven undated postcards of France feature the William the Conqueror Hostel. There are also 16 postcards of Japan dated 1912, featuring images around Nikko, with an additional 8 undated postcards containing images of Kasuga Jinjya.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes three printed items: a program for a musical event at the American Legation in 1911, a description for a Buddha for Todaiji Temple in Japan, and an article on Lucy's House, published in German.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series features primarily writings by Monroe family members, from letters to autobiographical and biographical pieces, along with some photographs, postcards, and a few newspaper clippings. Writings include letters by Polly Root Collier and Henry Stanton Monoe, Lucy Monroe Calhoun's niece and nephew, both of whom wrote extensive letters to family members during their stays with Calhoun in China, in 1911-1912 and 1933, respectively. These letters feature many of the same topics Calhoun covered in her memoir. Polly also wrote extensive letters regarding her own travels between 1953 and 1962. In addition, there are letters and an autobiography by William Stanton Monroe, mostly focusing on his business career, as well as a two letters by the patriarch of the family, Henry Stanton Monroe (1826-1903), written during his trip aboard a Cunard steamship in 1886. Anna Hammill Monroe wrote a biography of her son, Ernst Hamill Monroe, who died as a child. There is also a World War II letter written by Captain John Magruder, whose relationship to the Monroe family is unclear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The earliest letters by Mary Louise "Polly" Root Collier date from her stay with her Aunt and Uncle, Lucy and William Calhoun, in China during 1911-1912. The 63 letters (with one albumen group photograph) were primarily written to her mother. They describe her travel to Peking, as well as activities and life in the American Legation in Peiking. [They also closely second Lucy Monroe Calhoun's topics in her memoir.] Among the topics are sightseeing parties, meetings of the Purple Cows, and the political unrest of the period. Collier includes a hand-drawn map of Peking and the Legation Quarter. In addition, Collier outlines her travel to Tsing Tau, Shanghai, and Manila, Philippines.

Between 1953-1962 and undated, Collier wrote about 32 letters to a group of relatives," The Ranchers", who might have resided at White Gates Farm in Wayne, Illinois. Collier served on the Unitarian Service Committee's American Education Mission in Seoul, South Korea, between January and June 1954. Collier described her sightseeing and investigating community projects in several countries before reaching Seoul, including Hong Kong; Bangkok, Thailand; and Rangoon, Burma; along with several stops in India. Her letters from Seoul focus on her work, describing the territory, people, schools, children's games, and clothing, along with general conditions. Letters following her stay in Seoul generally provide detailed accounts of her travels, primarily in Europe, but in the Middle East and Asia as well. She describes her sightseeing trips, those she met, her forms of travel, along with general conditions in each country. One letter features a note in another hand, dated 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry S. Monroe wrote eighteen, often lengthy, letters to his parents, describing his travel to Peking, his stay with his Aunt Lucy, their activities and visitors, and visits to tourist attractions in Peking and beyond. He often mentions his taking photographs or filming events, along with his participation in plays. A background to the letters is the potential for invasion by the Japanese. In one letter he provides a romanized Chinese pronounciation guide. Includes his letter dated 1973 regarding William J. Calhoun's business background.

did.unittitle: William S. Monroe autobiography and letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains William S. Monroe's undate 17-page typescript autobiography, along with two unrelated personal letters he wrote in 1943 and 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises two letters Henry Stanton Monroe wrote to his wife and children from the Cunard steamship "Servia," which was traveling in the North Atlantic in July and August 1886. Monroe describes his activities on board, including meals, walks, sitting on deck, as well as the ship itself. He also records the weather, and discusses his fellow passengers and their entertainments, including board and card games, betting, music, reading, and "athletic games." He mentions a call for a mock trial in which he is to participate, and describes the burial at sea of a child who died on board. There is an additional letter to Polly Root Collier regarding her request to include the letters in the Newberry Library's holdings.

did.unittitle: Anna Hamill Monroe biography of Ernst Hamill Monroe

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anna Hamill Monroe wrote this undated, 42-page, typescript biography of her son, Ernst Hamill Monroe (1899-1904).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a typescript letter Captain Magruder wrote to his mother from Saipan, Marianas, where he was stationed. Magruder discussed fighting tactics used by American and Japanese forces. The letter was published in "The Parker Weekly;" a copy of the published version is inlcuded. It is unclear how this letter is related to the Monroe family.

did.unittitle: Polly Root Collier photographs and postcards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Polly Root Collier's collection of 26 photographs, 1 cabinet card, 1 photo postcard, and 3 postcards, featuring images taken of Collier and others, as well as landscapes, in Peking, China; Manila, Phillippines; and Seoul, South Korea. There are also two group photographs from family gatherings in the United States. Includes one 3/4-portrait of Lucy Monroe Calhoun. The majority of the photographs and postcards have captions in ink or pencil on the back. There are also 19 negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Albumen black-and-white portrait of possibly William S. Monroe seated at a piano. Photography studio is J. D. Toloff of Evansville, Ill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises two newspaper articles on New Year's Day parties held by the Monroe family in 1941 and 1946. One article is from the Chicago Tribune, the other is unattributed.
